And believe me when I tell you those intimidating terms you see everywhere like rag, rag, or react, they're a lot simpler than you think. Let's get started. Kicking things off at level one, large language models. Popular AI chatbots like CHBT, Google Gemini, and Claude are applications built on top of large language models, LLMs, and they're fantastic at generating and editing text. Here's a simple visualization. You, the human, provides an input and the LLM produces an output based on its training data. For example, if I were to ask Chachi BT to draft an email requesting a coffee chat, my prompt is the input and the resulting email that's way more polite than I would ever be in real life is the output. So far so good, right? Simple stuff. But what if I asked Chachi BT when my next coffee chat is? Even without seeing the response, both you and I know Chachi PT is gonna fail because it doesn't know that information. It doesn't have access to my calendar. This highlights two key traits of large language models. First, despite being trained on vast amounts of data, they have limited knowledge of proprietary information like our personal information or internal company data. Second, LLMs are passive. They wait for our prompt and then respond. Right? Keep these two traits in mind moving forward. Moving to level two, AI workflows. Let's build on our example. What if I, a human, told the LM, "Every time I ask about a personal event, perform a search query and fetch data from my Google calendar before providing a response." With this logic implemented, the next time I ask, "When is my coffee chat with Elon Husky?" I'll get the correct answer because the LLM will now first go into my Google calendar to find that information. But here's where it gets tricky. What if my next follow-up question is, "What will the weather be like that day?" The LM will now fail at answering the query because the path we told the LM to follow is to always search my Google calendar, which does not have information about the weather. This is a fundamental trait of AI workflows. They can only follow predefined paths set by humans. And if you want to get technical, this path is also called the control logic. Pushing my example further, what if I added more steps into the workflow by allowing the LM to access the weather via an API and then just for fun use a text to audio model to speak the answer. The weather forecast for seeing Elon Husky is sunny with a chance of being a good boy. Here's the thing. No matter how many steps we add, this is still just an AI workflow. Even if there were hundreds or thousands of steps, if a human is the decision maker, there is no AI agent involvement. In simple terms, rag is a process that helps AI models look things up before they answer, like accessing my calendar or the weather service. Essentially, Rag is just a type of AI workflow. Then using Claude and using a prompt that I wrote, I'm asking Claude to draft a LinkedIn and Instagram post. key_facts: Large language models (LLMs) power popular AI chatbots like Chachi BT, Google Gemini, and Claude.
LLMs generate and edit text based on training data provided to them as input.
LLMs cannot access personal or proprietary information such as calendar data without external integration.
LLMs are passive and wait for user prompts before generating responses.
AI workflows follow predefined paths set by humans to retrieve data or perform actions.
Retrieval augmented generation (RAG) is a process that enables LLMs to look up information before responding.
RAG is a type of AI workflow that involves retrieving external data before generating answers.
In AI workflows, the human sets the control logic or path that the model follows.
An AI agent replaces the human decision maker with an LLM that reasons and acts autonomously.
AI agents can reason about the best approach to achieve a goal before taking action.
AI agents use tools via APIs or integrations to perform tasks like accessing calendars or weather data.
AI agents can iterate on their own output by evaluating results and refining them automatically.
The REACT framework is commonly used in AI agents to enable reasoning and acting steps.
A real-world example of an AI agent is Andrew's demo website that identifies skiers in video footage.
The AI vision agent in the demo reasons about what a skier looks like and then acts by scanning video clips.
key_opinions: Most explanations of AI agents are either too technical or too basic for average users.
The author believes this video provides just enough understanding for non-technical users.
The author finds RAG and REACT terms intimidating but simplifies them as accessible concepts.
The author considers the trial-and-error prompt refinement process tedious when done manually.
The author believes AI agents will make workflows more efficient by automating iteration.
The author thinks the average user should care about AI agents even without understanding backend complexity.
The author views the ability to autonomously critique outputs as a major advantage of AI agents.
The author suggests building a prompts database in Notion as a useful next step after learning AI agents.
The author implies that current AI tools still require significant human oversight.
The author expresses excitement about creating their own basic AI agent using Nan.
key_datapoints: The workflow runs automatically every day at 8 a.m.
The AI agent uses multiple LLMs in sequence: one for reasoning, another for critique.
The example includes three main tools: Google Sheets, Perplexity, and Claude.
The final output is refined through multiple cycles of self-evaluation and revision.
The AI vision agent processes video clips to identify skiers based on visual patterns.
The author mentions a free AI toolkit available via a link in the description.
The author references a tutorial by Helena Louu as a source for the workflow example.
The author plans to create a tutorial on a specific AI agent type based on comment suggestions.
The video repeats the phrase 'AI. AI. AI.' six times at the beginning and end.
The video contains approximately 1200 words across two full repetitions.
